content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice one
Looks very similar to the medium puzzle "How Many Triangles and Rectangles".

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very nice puzzle, interesting concept, and I enjoyed coding my solution!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: (Did it for Yahya) A fun, creative ASCII Art puzzle that definitely made me see squares. Thanks for your contribution!

Very Great problem i would like to see this soon in CodinGame puzzle
why is the APPROVED area not working

The difficulty seems to be Easy instead of Medium.

Is the following input valid according to your statement? If so, your code doesn't seem to count the squares correctly.
11 21
+---+---+-+---+-+---+
|   |   | |   | |   |
++--++--+++-+-+-+---+
 |   |   |  |       |
 ++--++--++-+       |
  |   |   | |       |
  ++--++--+++-------+
   |   |   ||       |
   ++--++--++       |
    |   |   |       |
    +---+---+-------+

Sorry, I didn't add trailing spaces at the end of some of the lines. Please consider the above case with those added.

Please also consider the following case.

      +---+      
+---+-+---+-+---+
|   | +-+-+ |   |
+---+   |   +---+
|     +-+-+     |
+-----+-+-+-----+
|     +-+-+     |
+---+   |   +---+
|   | +-+-+ |   |
+---+-+---+-+---+
      +---+
Thank you :) You need to be level 20 and above to approve/reject puzzles unfortunately
Ah, ok, I see now. Thank you, I will work my way to reach that level haha.

I've updated the difficulty to Easy.

As for the provided input, my test cases are all aligned on the small square for now. I can see how this might confusing though. Perhaps I should add more test cases?

Yes, please do. Alternatively, add a constraint which disallows such cases.

While you're revising the cases, please also transpose some of the figures so that [[R]] > [[C]] in 33-50% of the cases.

Thanks.

That's indeed an extreme example you gave!

You may also have to emphasise that the squares must have + as their corners. For instance, in my second example above, it looks likes there are some 5x9 squares, but there really aren't any.

Yes, but I mean, they don't have to be intersecting, so there aren't 5x9 squares. Removing the irrelevant characters would result in something like this:

                 
+---+-+   +-+---+
|     +-+-+     |
+       |       +
|       +       |
+-----+-+-+-----+
|       +       |
+       |       +
|     +-+-+     |
+---+-+   +-+---+

I have relaxed the constraint on the sizes and offsets of the squares and have added more test cases that have more rows than columns. The input

11 17
      +---+      
+---+-+---+-+---+
|   | +-+-+ |   |
+---+   |   +---+
|     +-+-+     |
+-----+-+-+-----+
|     +-+-+     |
+---+   |   +---+
|   | +-+-+ |   |
+---+-+---+-+---+
      +---+      

should now yield 12 squares.

Nice change!

Goal
* Please move this sentence:

This puzzle uses ASCII characters to "draw" figures containing squares.

into the first paragraph. This will give the reader early context for why "visual equal-length" needs a definition.

* Please change "is just an example" to "are just examples".

* Consider adding the labels h = 2, h = 3, h = 4 and h = 5 below the top 4 examples for better illustration.

* "A + character denotes intersecting - and | characters": they aren't always intersecting (crossing); consider replacing "intersecting" with "the meeting point of".

* No intersecting sides are shown in the bottom 5 examples. Consider removing the first example and adding one which shows squares with intersecting sides.

Thanks.
Done, thank you!

In the last paragraph, is the intended focus actually on "shared" sides rather than "intersecting" sides? In the bottom 5 examples, no sides are truly intersecting. A case where "intersecting" applies is when two large squares overlap like this:

+-------+
|       |
|     +-+-----+ Two sides intersect at the 2nd + in this row.
|     | |     |
+-----+-+     | Two sides intersect at the 2nd + in this row.
      |       |
      +-------+
Ah I interpreted intersecting sides differently from intersecting squares. Have updated the diagram accordingly.
No worries! It's ok now.
